articles.headline: World Falls for American Media, Even as It Sours on America
articles.snippet: After the 9/11 terrorist attacks, the White House wanted major media companies to help improve the U.S. image abroad. That hasn’t panned out.
articles.abstract: After the 9/11 terrorist attacks, the White House wanted major media companies to help improve the U.S. image abroad. That hasn’t panned out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after the attacks on 9/11, a delegation of high-level media executives, including the heads of every major studio, met several times with White House officials, including at least once with President Bush’s former top strategist, Karl Rove, to discuss ways that the entertainment industry could play a part in improving the image of the United States overseas.

articles.headline: Media and Retailers Both Built Black Friday
articles.snippet: When assessing blame for the trampling death of a salesclerk, the news media should include themselves.
articles.abstract: When assessing blame for the trampling death of a salesclerk, the news media should include themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: This weekend, news reports were full of finger-wagging over the death by trampling of a temporary worker, Jdimytai Damour, at a Wal-Mart store in Long Island on Friday. His death, the coverage suggested, was a symbol of a broken culture of consumerism in which people would do anything for a bargain.

articles.headline: Autoworkers Worry More Givebacks Are in Store
articles.snippet: If Detroit is to win a bailout this week, the United Automobile Workers may have to agree to big cost cuts.
articles.abstract: If Detroit is to win a bailout this week, the United Automobile Workers may have to agree to big cost cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Two years ago, Ron Gettelfinger, president of the United Automobile Workers union, offered a grim prognosis for the auto industry to union members at the group’s convention in Las Vegas.

articles.headline: A Generation of Local TV Anchors Is Signing Off
articles.snippet: Cost-cutting at many local stations includes the big salaries commanded by news anchors.
articles.abstract: Cost-cutting at many local stations includes the big salaries commanded by news anchors.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the most familiar voices in Denver is about to sign off for the last time.

articles.headline: Deep Discounts Draw Shoppers, but Not Profits
articles.snippet: The discounts that drove shoppers to stores were so steep that many ailing chains may be no better off in the long run.
articles.abstract: The discounts that drove shoppers to stores were so steep that many ailing chains may be no better off in the long run.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sales in the nation’s stores were strong over the weekend, to the relief of retailers that had been expecting a holiday shopping period as slow as the overall economy.

articles.headline: Each Player in Big Three Is Devising Its Own Plan
articles.snippet: The Detroit automakers will have diverging agendas as they take their second run at Congress for federal aid.
articles.abstract: The Detroit automakers will have diverging agendas as they take their second run at Congress for federal aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Detroit automakers have been lumped together for decades as the Big Three, and for good reason; their goals have usually been aligned.

articles.headline: A Handpicked Team for a Sweeping Shift in Foreign Policy
articles.snippet: Barack Obama’s national security team includes two veteran cold warriors and a political rival whose records are all more hawkish than that of the new president.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama’s national security team includes two veteran cold warriors and a political rival whose records are all more hawkish than that of the new president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As President-elect Barack Obama introduces his national security team on Monday, it includes two veteran cold warriors and a political rival whose records are all more hawkish than that of the new president who will face them in the White House Situation Room.

articles.headline: Cheer Fades as Stocks Plunge 9%
articles.snippet: The announcement that the recession began in December 2007 came on a day when the Dow dropped more than 7 percent.
articles.abstract: The announcement that the recession began in December 2007 came on a day when the Dow dropped more than 7 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: December blew in with a mighty chill on Wall Street.

articles.headline: Officials Vow to Act Amid Signs of Long Recession
articles.snippet: With word that the U.S. officially sank into a recession last December, the Fed chairman and the Treasury secretary said they would use all the tools at their disposal.
articles.abstract: With word that the U.S. officially sank into a recession last December, the Fed chairman and the Treasury secretary said they would use all the tools at their disposal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United States economy officially sank into a recession last December, which means that the downturn is already longer than the average for all recessions since World War II, according to the committee of economists responsible for dating the nation’s business cycles.
